message_1: Assuming $f(z)=\dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)}$, find the value of the Fourier transform of $f$ evaluated at $x=3$.
message_2:
The Fourier transform of a function $f(z)$ is defined as:

$$\mathcal{F}\{f\}(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(z) e^{-2\pi ixz} dz$$

In this case, we have $f(z) = \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)}$. We want to find the Fourier transform of $f$ evaluated at $x=3$. So, we need to compute the following integral:

$$\mathcal{F}\{f\}(3) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} dz$$

To solve this integral, we can use the method of complex contour integration. We will consider the integral along a semicircular contour in the upper half-plane, which includes the pole at $z=i$. The contour integral is given by:

$$\oint_C \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} dz$$

By the residue theorem, this integral is equal to $2\pi i$ times the residue of the integrand at the pole $z=i$. To find the residue, we can use the formula:

$$\text{Res}_{z=i} \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} = \lim_{z\to i} (z-i) \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz}$$

$$= \lim_{z\to i} \dfrac{1}{(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz}$$

Evaluating the limit, we get:

$$\text{Res}_{z=i} \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} = \dfrac{1}{(i-2)} e^{-6\pi i^2} = \dfrac{1}{(i-2)} e^{6\pi}$$

Now, we can compute the contour integral:

$$\oint_C \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} dz = 2\pi i \cdot \dfrac{1}{(i-2)} e^{6\pi}$$

As the contour integral is equal to the sum of the integrals along the real axis and the semicircular arc, we have:

$$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} dz + \int_{\text{arc}} \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} dz = 2\pi i \cdot \dfrac{1}{(i-2)} e^{6\pi}$$

The integral along the semicircular arc vanishes as the radius goes to infinity, so we are left with:

$$\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \dfrac{1}{(z-i)(z-2)} e^{-6\pi iz} dz = 2\pi i \cdot \dfrac{1}{(i-2)} e^{6\pi}$$

Therefore, the Fourier transform of $f$ evaluated at $x=3$ is:

$$\mathcal{F}\{f\}(3) = 2\pi i \cdot \dfrac{1}{(i-2)} e^{6\pi}$$
